Winston's weary eyes moved towards the photos of the crime scene. The wrestling ring, normally throbbing with life, seemed void in the ominous light of the flash. Isabelle's life had ended here, in the very wrestling ring that was part of the event Lance was directing.

As he looked closely at a photo of the bloodied mat, his eyes drifted to a piece of prop laying just out of the boundary of the ring. Lance and his crew handled these props, and Lance himself had been seen practicing with props similar to the one near the crime scene - a trident. He knew Lance had a penchant for ancient weapons, often seen studying or collecting them. It seemed these props were more than just set dressing to Lance.

Winston scratched his chin, pondering. Lance's life revolved around his shows. He loved directing them. This wrestling match, the scene of the crime, was one such event he was in charge of.

With a final sigh, the detective gathered his things. There still was much left to uncover. Soon after, he found himself in the production area of the show, meeting with Lance.

"Lance, I presume?" Winston asked, offering a hand. The man nodded, taking Winston's hand into a firm grip.

"Winston. I'm... I'm here about your wife, Isabelle."

Lance's eyes clouded over for a second before he pushed past the emotions, "Let's talk then, detective."

context:
When the silver screen flickered with an unexpected explosion, claiming the life of innocent Chloe, seasoned Detective Winston stepped in to unravel the deadly scandal entwining suspects Ruby and Ebony.

Despite the night's residue of tobacco clinging to his garment, Detective Winston took a deep inhale as he approached Ruby. He pulled out a crumpled picture of Chloe from his pocket and sighed, replaying the explosion at the movie theatre over and over in his mind, as well as the image of Jake, the man he's spotted Chloe with on numerous clandestine dates.

"Ruby," he began. His voice was low and weary. "I understand that you and Chloe had planned a sister-courtship to the movies last night."

A flicker of surprise crossed Ruby's face. "Why, yes. Chloe wanted to see that new film, The Scarlet Phoenix. We enjoyed a night at the theater till the very end. Nobody else entered or left the theater during our stay - it was just us."

"Interesting," muttered Winston. "And there were eyewitnesses confirming that you were the last person seen with Chloe?"

"Yes," said Ruby hesitatingly,"We departed together."

"Interesting," muttered Winston, making no further comment. Instead, he considered the reported vision of Ruby seeing Chloe kissing another man. Another man who turned out to be Jake.

"I understand that you might have feelings for Jake. Is that right?" Winston questioned, watching Ruby carefully.

Ruby hesitated, playing with the locket around her neck. “Yes, I suppose that's true,” she admitted, but never meeting his gaze.

The detective changed the angle of the conversation. “I've heard tales about your psychic abilities, Ruby. You tend to see dangerous things. Your visions included dreadful bomb scenarios back when you were in the military, right?”

"I've had visions," Ruby replied defensively. "Visions are often ambiguous. They can symbolize various scenarios. I did see Chloe, Chloe kissing another man... Jake. And yes, during my service, I’ve seen how war and destruction unfold, even how to use grenades."

"I can imagine," Winston said, thinking to himself. Connecting the dots, he continued, "Did you know that Jake and Chloe were secretly seeing each other?"

Ruby's apprehension told Winston everything he needed to know. "Yes, I knew. Chloe told me about it," she said, her face growing pale.

"Did you also stay behind after the movie, in the theatre?" Winston asked, looking at Ruby sternly.

"We both enjoyed the ending credits music, so we stayed till the end. I distinctly remember walking out of the theatre last night, but... alone," Ruby said, hinting at her absence following the movie's completion.

Winston allowed a moment's pause before continuing on. "Ruby, where did you go after the movie ended?"

"I went to my brother's house," Ruby's reply was swift, a touch too swift.

Winston blinked, remembering her brother's notorious reputation as an arms dealer, and Ruby's own military background. "That's... convenient."

"I suppose it is," Ruby replied quietly, eyes fixed on the policeman's tired, yet zealous gaze. The meeting was concluded with that, leaving Winston with the chilling evening wind and another lead in Chloe's puzzling demise.

Winston glanced at the movie ticket stub Ebony held, noting that it was for the same film as Chloe. He squinted at Ebony, a Black man with a disheveled appearance, suggesting a disconnect.

"You were here at the theatre when the event happened, then?" Winston asked, gesturing at the ticket. Ebony was indeed there before the movie started, now confirmed by the timing on his ticket.

A confirmed nod came from Ebony, who avoided meeting Winston’s gaze. "Yeah, I was here. Same movie as her." His voice dropped lower. "When the incident occurred during the movie screening. Chloe... She didn't make it."

Winston hesitated, knowing Chloe's death wasn't the only thing he needed to discuss today. Throughout their conversation, Winston noticed a limp in Ebony's step, bruises, and a sharp wince when he moved a certain way. "Looks like you've got some injuries there," Winston remarked casually.

Though he spoke offhandedly, Ebony was quick to brush it off, often changing the subject when questioned about his injuries, which drew Winston’s attention. More so than before, Winston observed, people tended to notice when someone was deliberately avoiding a topic.

Trying not to push too far, Winston paused momentarily - but then he remembered the drug bag found in Ebony’s possession at the theater. He recalled a report from resident neighbors as well, Mr. & Mrs. Davenport, stating that they've often seen Ebony limping into his apartment late in the night, disheveled and pained. Further arousing suspicion was the doorman’s testimony, reporting a similar disheveled state during the late-night arrivals.

Remaining cognizant of the consequences to Ebony’s situation if he were to be caught using drugs, Winston pressed on, "Ebony, I've heard you've been behaviorally inconsistent lately. And there’s the matter of the confiscated drug bag. Do you understand the negative implications this could have?"

Ebony visibly flinched. His demeanor took on a nervous edge, scratching his arm as it often did when he felt cornered. Winston’s gaze hardened, feeling certain that Ebony was hiding something.

“I...uh got to use the restroom," Ebony stammered before rushing off, undoubtedly the effects of the drugs kicking in.

Winston decided to follow, needing more answers. Was Ebony the reason behind Chloe's demise? Was this why he'd jeopardize his situation with drug addiction? With renewed determination, Winston set off after him.

As Winston neared the restroom, he was eerily reminded of the nearly empty crime scene — a movie theatre mid-showing. He shuddered at the thought of the panic that ensued when the grenade went off during the screening.

But there was no time for that now, he had a suspect to confront.

context:
In the cold echo of a deserted hockey rink, Otis was found dead from a grenade explosion, and now Detective Winston must decipher the clues, suspecting Ervin and Darnell are somehow involved.

Detective Winston rubbed his temples while the facts flickered across his computer screen. Otis, the victim, would most definitely be missed. His usual vibrant energy that filled the hockey rink was replaced by cold, solemn silence.

Some contradictions needed to be resolved. The crime scene at the hockey rink was empty, both at the time of the murder and throughout the investigation. Winston's only lead was Darnell, a Black man and an old military pal of Otis. Winston heard that Darnell had recently switched his career to become a solo hiking guide. Indeed, a remarkable part of his solo hikes was his ability to help hikers they came across on the way overcome environmental dangers—a way of applying his skills acquired from his military service. It was an unusual practice in the industry but allowed due to his military expertise in bomb disposal—an odd career choice for a man of such skills.

Winston drove to the outskirts of the town, where Darnell lived in a remote cabin. Darnell's solo job didn't always welcome company, but that didn't seem to bother him. Rumor had it that he uses his military skills to help strangers on the trails overcome environmental dangers—detonating falling rocks, perhaps?

Once in the cabin, Winston noticed several hiking supplies meticulously arranged. He inspected them and found, hidden strategically among the normal hiking necessities—food, water, emergency kit—were several small explosives. Chills ran down his spine as he remembered a recent break-in at a military base.

"I see you have explosives mixed with your hiking guide supplies,” Winston said, trying to evoke a reaction.

Darnell replied calmly, “Those are just for emergencies.”

Listening to Darnell, Winston remembered that Otis had been friendly with him. Otis was always open with Darnell about his daily habits, even shared his calendar with him. Darnell was the only person who knew Otis would be alone at the hockey rink that evening.

On his way out, Winston remembered Darnell's frank words, "I don't like to hang out after work.”

It seemed somewhat true, living far from town, working alone, and being prone to avoid after-work hangouts. Winston thought to himself: Darnell did like to be alone. It all seemed so strange, the grenade murder, the empty hockey rink, Darnell’s distant demeanor. However, he couldn't draw any obvious conclusions just yet. He needed more.

Detective Winston sat on the chilly bleachers of the local hockey rink, a place as familiar to him as it was to Ervin, the mild-mannered Rabbi who had never missed a game. The rink was still splattered with telltale signs of the merciless violence that had taken place there. Otis had been killed during a game, a seemingly jovial event turned nightmarish by the unexpected detonation of a grenade.

Taking his eyes off the crime scene momentarily, he scanned his surroundings and spotted his next person of interest: Ervin, a massive hockey fan, and a staunch supporter of their local team. His presence at the game had been expected, as his dedicated attendance was part of the everyday routine. Some of the spectators had mentioned Ervin stepping out of the stadium briefly, interestingly around the same time Otis was killed.

Not missing his beat, Winston approached Rabbi Ervin, who was still in deep shock at the loss of a fellow spectator and friend, “Rabbi Ervin?”

The Rabbi looked up to meet the detective's prying eyes, “I am Ervin, indeed. And you are?”

“I am Detective Winston, investigating the recent unfortunate event.”

Observing Ervin's face closely, Winston began: "The strangest thing happened a few days ago. Otis came to me and told me he was planning to go to the authorities. He knew something was off, dangerous even. I guess we didn't react quickly enough. He mentioned your name, Ervin, and something about another life before the synagogue…”

Ervin was quiet, his gaze distant but thoughtful. "Yes, Otis did confront me. He saw me moving some funds around. He saw, Detective, he saw me committing the crime which I've regretted every day since," Ervin confessed.

Winston let the confession sink in before shifting the subject subtly. "I heard you were in the military?"

Ervin smiled, just barely, nodding with a touch of pride. "Yes, I am a former military officer. Had a special training in demolitions you see, before I found my calling in religion."

Winston returned his smile, "I suppose it's a bit of a leap from demolitions to the pulpit."

"Just a tad," Ervin's laughter is soft. "But the old life stays with you in ways you wouldn't expect. I've got a collection of war memorabilia back home. host some of my friends over sometimes, they marvel at these artifacts. I even got grenades in there. Nothing active, of course. They tend to catch the eye.”

Winston excused himself, leaving Ervin to mourn at the crash of their sanctuary of play turned battleground.

context:

Winston let out a pensive sigh as the medical examiner rattled off the factors that spelled foul play, namely the shrapnel directly linked to a grenade. When you see something new, you remember it, he mused.

The town had been buzzing since Darnell's angry outburst in the synagogue last Sunday. Bystanders had recounted to Winston how Darnell, a Black man with a strong presence, had been shouting at a particular customer he had been consulting with, before the outburst escalated and he stormed off into the synagogue. The same customer, Walter Harrison, who Darnell had consulted with before he stormed off into the synagogue, had recounted it to him with fear in his voice.

"And you say you were trembling after the confrontation, Mr. Harrison?" Winston asked after the customer finished recounting Darnell's worrying reaction.

"N-not just a confrontation," the distressed customer stammered, "Darnell, our Rabbi, he lost it – punching the walls, shouting at everyone. There’s still a visible dent where he hit."

Winston gave a slight nod, “Thank you for your cooperation,” he said before heading toward the synagogue to track down Rabbi Darnell.

Darnell Thornberg, the Rabbi, met Winston's inquiring gaze coolly. Darnell had a hardened look - the clear evidence of his military past. He was known in town as a former military officer with specialized training in demolitions. Nothing could erase that part of his life.

"Quite an impressive array of memorabilia here, Rabbi," Winston remarked, scanning the room filled with various wartime relics like grenades and medals from Darnell's service days. "Your friends often tell stories of you proudly showing these off."

"Careful with those, Detective, they are from my time in the service," Darnell replied, with a hint of nostalgia creeping into his tone. "My friends, they have a way of making things sound more dramatic."

Winston was further intrigued by the hint of gossip he received from one of Darnell's neighbors, "You know, Otis had been vocal lately. He saw something he shouldn't about Darnell and the synagogue funds. Even said he was planning to go to the authorities."

With that information, Winston pitched it to Darnell, "I hear Otis saw something alarming involving you and the synagogue's funds. Heard he was seriously considering going to the authorities."

Darnell stiffened noticeably, his cool gaze flickered for a moment. "Otis talks too much," he muttered, a subtle hint of annoyance in his tone.

Just as he was about to leave, a troubling fact popped back into his mind - Otis. Otis had seen Darnell embezzling funds from the Synagogue and Darnell knew that. Winston marked it down mentally and with a brisk nod to Rabbi Darnell, made his exit. Feeling the sharp gaze of Darnell boring into his back, he needed no further confirmation.

The pieces were neatly aligning, like pieces of a puzzle, Winston could see it - But it wasn't his place to tell the story, rather gather it. So with another sigh, he slid into the driver's seat and drove off. The knot in his gut tightened as he pulled away from the synagogue - he knew his work here was far from done.

Winston pulled the collar of his jacket up and stepped into the freezing cold of the hockey rink. Alone in the rink, he squinted under the heat of the artificial light to read the deserted stands and make out the chalk lines: "Just a man and his routine...Otis was always here at this time, when no one else was present...So why Otis? Why here?"

Hours later, Winston found himself wading through the mud and foliage of a nearby hiking trail. He was there to meet Andrew, the local hiking guide, a formally trained Bomb Disposal Technician in the military, and a close friend of Otis. Andrew's hiking business had been losing traction for quite some time. His soldier-like formality was still intact, standing tall despite the fall of his flailing business, which was evident through alarming financial reports showing consistent and increasing negative balance in his accounts.

"Right this way, detective." Andrew offered, leading him through the dense woods with the authority and precision that only a man with his specialized training would possess. Andrew diligently used his army skills to ensure the safety of hikers from any potential environmental dangers on their guided tours.

"Andrew-" Winston began, striding to keep up with the trained speedwalker, "I was told you two were close. And you had asked Otis about his insurance policy recently. Care to shed some light on that?"

Andrew did not look back as he continued walking. "Sure did. Otis had been open about his routine. I always knew when he was at the rink or off somewhere else. As for his insurance, he had approached me for advice and later updated it, naming me the beneficiary."

As they neared Andrew's hiking spot, Winston noticed a military-grade tent with tools, knives, ropes, canned food supplies, and hidden among them, explosives. Andrew's intense secrecy hinted at something more - these were not just regular hiking supplies.

"Quite a collection here, Andrew. Comes in handy during your hikes I presume?" Winston asked casually. Andrew replied with a nod, "It's an efficient system. Every item serves a purpose."

Before Winston could probe further, his phone buzzed, indicating a call from the station. "Just bear with me, Andrew," Winston excused himself. Andrew shuffled uncomfortably nearby, sparked a further conversation about Otis' recent insurance update.

A forensic update from the station linked the lethal grenade to the recent military base theft!

"Do you mind if we take this conversation downtown, Andrew?" Winston turned around. Andrew stood tall, showing no signs of discomfort. He simply nodded and followed Winston, all the while maintaining his usual formal demeanor.

In the shimmering opulence of a luxury restaurant, Roderick's life was abruptly ended by a pistol's merciless blow; now Detective Winston must untangle the web of Oscar and Ebony's testimonies.

Detective Winston sat down in the interview room with a sigh, glancing at the woman before him. Ebony, with her dark brown skin and black hair, her face etched with confusion and a hint of defiance painted an intriguing story.

"So, Ebony, let me understand this," Winston began. "You were discussing matters about your personal life?" Winston asked.

"I was giving an update on my recent activities," Ebony said, a look of challenge in her eyes.

Just then, a friend entered the interview room unexpectedly. A look of concern was etched on his face. "May I have a moment with Ebony, Detective?" he asked, pleading with his eyes.

Winston sighed and nodded, exiting the room. He knew from the friend that not only was Ebony not given the recognition she was considered for, but the decision had come from her acquaintance Roderick – he had outright refused to consider her for a project. Feeling slighted, she had a heated argument with Roderick.

Winston knew, Ebony was capable. She had won several shooting competitions but her recent activity showed a disturbing pattern. His colleague had told him earlier that Ebony was seen practicing with a pistol at the shooting range. A pistol that matched the murder weapon used.

Further investigation led him to a public event. Ebony was present with companions, putting on a friendly face and a casual mask of normalcy. A perfect alibi. But Winston wasn't entirely convinced just yet.

He recalled a field policeman questioning Ebony about her recent activities. A brave woman confident in her role, but her world had been recently rocked by disappointment.

A rival had been promoted instead of her. And Ebony, a competitive woman herself, seemed to be harboring some hard feelings.

Winston made his way back to the interrogation room. Ebony, his current person of interest, had recently purchased the same kind of pistol used in Roderick's murder. That fact alone made him cautiously alert.

This case was far from over, leaving Winston to piece together the complex web of evidence and suspect motives. He sighed, looking across the table at the woman in front of him, contemplating the next steps in his investigation.

Detective Winston sighed as he ran his fingers through his hair looking over the crime scene photographs. The sight of Roderick, a successful entrepreneur, found at a luxury restaurant, oddly felt disheartening to Winston.

From his collected evidence, a pistol registered to Oscar's name was used to shoot Roderick. Winston thought back to the office reports he'd reviewed: Oscar recently losing his job and multiple reports of conflicts at the office. This was a man grappling with a world that was unraveling.

As he drove to Oscar's residence for an interview, Winston couldn't shake the image of the domestic dispute reports mentioned by Oscar's children. They fell into a pattern with Oscar's recent purchase of a gun and his prescribed therapy for divorce-related depression.

Oscar greeted Winston in the living room. The house was silent, a portrait of a family interrupted. Winston couldn't help but glance at a family picture on the wall – Oscar and Roderick, faces beaming, their children huddled close.

"Been quite a month, hasn't it, Oscar?" Winston casually inquired.

Oscar nodded, not meeting Winston's eye. "Sure has been."

Winston got straight to business. "What led you to buy the gun?"

Oscar's face shifted slightly, attempting to mask his discomfort. "Just felt the need to protect my family...I never wanted it to be used..."

Winston reeled back. That was unanticipated. "Interesting...What can you tell me about the event at the restaurant?"

"Ah." Oscar hesitated, his fingers tensed around the armrest. "We were there for a private party, I'd proposed a toast. Had everyone's attention on me for a while... it was supposed to be a chance for Roderick and I to discuss our divorce..."

"So you two were having marital problems."

"Yup. We... I mean, I still loved him very much. But he was going to leave me. I just wanted to talk to him...That’s all."

Winston inclined his head, taking in every word. Here was a man on the brink, a man pushed to the very edge.

"Alright, Oscar. I appreciate your cooperation." As Winston went for the door, he turned back and looked at Oscar, sadly pondering the tale of a story only half told and yet becoming all too clear to him.

Detective Winston, staring at the rain streaming down his office window, absentmindedly stirred his lukewarm coffee. Another murder landed on his desk. The victim, Roderick. The list of facts pertaining to Brianna, a tenacious teacher suspected to be involved, seemed to be a never-ending stream of potential leads.

Sifting through stacks of evidence, he came across a statement from Roderick, Brianna's boss, refusing to consider her for a promotion at work. Winston placed it on top of the pile as he planned his approach. The next piece of evidence was a statement from a valet at the luxury restaurant. Winston made his way over to the shooting range. A police report detailed that a pistol Brianna recently purchased and practiced with here was identical to the one used to kill Roderick.

The shooting range was winding down for the evening. Winston was able to speak to the range officer, "So, Brianna's been coming here often?"

"Yeah, she's really dedicated. You wouldn't believe it but she's won several competitions here," the range officer commented, leading Winston to the lanes where Brianna often practiced.

Within his stack of evidence, Winston found a copy of the restaurant's reservation list, confirming Brianna's presence at Classico's that night. More evidence from his stack showed that Brianna had been ambitiously seeking the same promotion at the school she worked, the promotion Roderick instead received.

He soon found himself speaking with the restaurant staff. The valet, waitstaff, and even some kitchen staff all recalled seeing Brianna leave the restaurant around the same time as Roderick. Most interestingly, they all bore witness to an argument that Brianna had with Roderick during dinner.

Next, Winston stopped by the school where Roderick worked. A fellow teacher revealed how deeply disappointed Brianna was when Roderick got the promotion instead of her.

With the collected evidence, Winston knew he needed to confront Brianna.

Brianna nodded, "Yes, I spill my frustrations on paper targets, helps me to stay focused."

"Do you dine at Classico's often," Winston asked casually.

"Yes, once every so often," replied Brianna, "I’m a regular there."

"I’m sure they recognized you the night Roderick was killed," Winston said, subtly sliding the copy of the reservations list across the desk.

"I suppose," Brianna said, cleaning her glasses, "But isn’t it a little strange that a busy detective like you is asking about dinner plans?”

Winston shrugged and stood up. "Well, duty calls. It was nice chatting with you, Brianna." Making his leave, Winston thought about all the pieces he had gathered and how they all seemed to point to Brianna.

Winston was nursing a black coffee and flipping through the case file when the first cracks of dawn speckled the dreary sky. The victim, Roderick, had been a stand-up entrepreneur before he caught a bullet. Roderick had agreed to meet his husband, Ivory, to discuss their divorce plans on the day he died. Ivory, a white man with a worn expression, had been mentioned in the case file as someone who had been struggling to come to terms with the end of their relationship.

"Why flee when you're already getting a divorce?" Winston found himself murmuring to his empty, scarcely lit office. A note from a confidential source in the case file revealed that Ivory had heard from Roderick that he was planning to leave him.

Winston's musings were interrupted by a phone call. It was Ivory's son, Josh. He cheerfully announced his excitement about the languid summer that lay ahead of him, spent at home. Winston rubbed his eyes, cracked his back, and decided it was time to pay Ivory a visit.

Ivory lived in a modest suburban home. The early morning dew lightly wet the sidewalk and the chill hung in the air. His silver sedan with premium rims was parked in the driveway, just as Ivory's neighbor had mentioned. She'd been seeing their car parked there with the windows down at all times lately. Upon inspection, Winston could see a receipt for a large, black suitcase on the passenger seat. He made a note of it.

Ivory, on the other hand, looked like a shadow of his former self. Tired eyes, unkempt hair, and the flicker of sadness in his eyes confirmed his ongoing love for Roderick, despite everything. The sad fact that he had been forced to say goodbye to his job a month ago only added to his woe. His therapist had been supporting him through the divorce-related depression, but with Roderick's sudden demise, things had taken a turn for the worse.

Winston was offered a cup of coffee while he casually asked Ivory about the night of Roderick's death. Ivory offered up the information that he had proposed a toast at the private party right before Roderick was shot, diverting everyone's attentions momentarily away from the man. After having his fill of the tepid liquid, Winston got up, thanked Ivory for his time, and walked back towards his car.

The sound of his shoes crunching the freshly dewed gravel, Winston lit up a cigarette. He drove away eventually, leaving Ivory in his rearview mirror, standing in the doorway. He gave an inward groan thinking about the mountain of paperwork waiting for him at the station.

In this mess, a voice echoed in his head, 'Heard Ivory was in therapy. Depression, they said.'

It was a long day and Winston was certain, it was going to be a long case.

context:
In the chilling underbelly of a secluded bunker, Donald's life was snuffed out by deadly snake venom and now, it's up to the sharp and relentless Detective Winston to shake the truth out of his prime suspects, Jay and Ivory.

I was inside the local café, mulling over the case when I saw Ivory. She was a regular here, always engrossed in a murder mystery novel, which somehow comforted me in a way. Detective work made you appreciate the mundane things about life. Her dark skin and tightly coiled black hair stood out as she sat by the window, lost in the pages of her book.

"Ivory," I greeted her as I approached, "how are things?"

She took a moment, reached down into her bag, and pulled out a specific thrilling novel titled "Perfect Crime". She glanced up from the book and responded, "Oh, hello Winston. Just the usual."

I looked down at her book, the title striking a chord, "This one any good?"

Ivory got excited and spoke in vivid detail about the perfect crime plotted in the novel. Her enthusiasm around the theme of crime and the specific details almost perturbed me, but I chose to focus on the dialogue at hand.

We mentioned Donald, and how he had plans to head to the bunker. Ivory froze for a moment before returning to her normal composure. "He trusted you," I said, "would have let you in the bunker."

"The bunker? Yeah, I know the place. Donald used to talk about it," she replied, trying to sound nonchalant. But I could discern a hint of unease in her voice, the knowledge of the bunker and everything that had transpired there appeared to weigh heavy on her.

Ivory had been in a gang with Donald. Back in the day, they used to own this town, running around and kicking up dust wherever they went. Time moved on, things had changed, but the past lingered in Ivory's fear of her past crimes revealing themselves.

Donald had confided in me once that he discovered Ivory was still engaging in criminal activities. She had psychic abilities which made her an asset in their criminal past and perhaps, in her current endeavours.

The clang of the door brought me back to the café. Ivory had left, the sunshine reflected off her hair as she headed down the street, her murder mystery novel tucked securely under her arm. The people in the café moved again, life resumed while questions circled in my mind. Along with Ivory, I left the café: one looking to uphold justice, and the other, potentially, to evade it.

Winston walked down the long, subterranean corridor again, guiding his flashlight along the intricately detailed blueprints of the bunker he held in his hands - blueprints that once belonged to the experienced Jay. Once housed in the station, this giant underground maze was a known territory to Jay, of course, but to Winston, it was all foreign.

Hours later, in a makeshift interrogation center in the surface barracks, Winston eyed the familiar face of the missionary, Jay.

"I've seen the blueprints, Jay," he said simply, watching the other man's face.

"Oh, those?" Jay replied, a light airiness showing in his reply. "I spent quite a bit of time down there when I was stationed at this bunker. I could still walk through it blindfolded."

"And isolated…" Winston added, his gaze never leaving Jay's face. It was a known fact that the underground bunker locked from the inside and the only two keys existed – one with Donald and the other with Jay. It had been established earlier that Jay and Donald were the only ones inside the fortified bunker during the time of Donald's death.

Jay didn't respond immediately. He looked disinterested, detached. He finally spoke up, "I guess Donald had started to suspect, huh? He confronted me about it a few days ago."

"You've done some snake handling, haven't you?" - Winston asked.

Jay chuckled. "A rite of passage, they call it. Over there in the region with a high snake population, it’s a trial, a blessing, an exorcism.” His tone held a grim, respectful distance.

Winston nodded, "I've heard it's common among missionaries to learn about snakebite remedies as well."

"A living antidote, in case of a bite, that's not common knowledge."- Jay answered, leaning back in his chair.

"Were you aware, Jay," Winston began, "that Donald discovered certain… irregularities?"

Jay's eyes flickered to Winston's for the first time. "Irregularities? You mean the smuggling?" He admitted.

Winston let the confession hang in the air between them.

"I was using the missions to distribute certain substances, that part is true." Jay said.

"You got trained here, in the bunker. Now you distribute substances, in religious ruse. " His tone turned pointedly menacing.

He leaned in slightly, resting his elbows on the tabletop, "Discovery of which, Jay, would do a lot more than tarnish a reputation."

Jay remained silent, his eyes hardening and body rigid, awaiting the impending threat the detective presented.

Winston suddenly backed off, taking his notes and exiting the room, leaving Jay alone among his thoughts.

context:
In the chilling underbelly of a secluded bunker, Donald's life was snuffed out by deadly snake venom and now, it's up to the sharp and relentless Detective Winston to shake the truth out of his prime suspects, Darnell and Autumn.

Winston squinted in the dim bunker light, glancing around at the empty shelves and overturned furniture; the area decked with caution tapes. Something didn't sit right, there was always more to the story than what laid bare, Winston knew this.

His latest lead led him to Autumn, the only person Donald would have willingly let inside his survival bunker. Before Donald’s unanticipated retreat to his bunker, he had mentioned his intent to her. The two of them were old acquaintances, sharing a history few knew of, having been in a criminal gang together. Donald was more trusting than most, in fact, Autumn was the only person he would trust when it came to sharing such a secluded spot. His survival bunker was his safe haven, where he was known to retreat when the world became too loud.

Maybe it was her psychic abilities that drew him in - Autumn did have a knack for knowing things before they happened. Or maybe it was her unique collection of pets she so lovingly tended to. Her pets came with a singular bite, a serpentine collection that few dared to keep. As the sole caretaker of these reptiles, she also had intimate knowledge of their venom, which she knew could prove deadly for Donald.

Even fewer knew about Autumn's illicit past, dark secrets tangled up with crimes committed years ago; secrets that could have turned disastrous had they been revealed. She feared the consequences that awaited her, fearing her darkest secrets could be unveiled leading to her undoing.

And then there was Donald. He had always been a reliable man. A straight shooter who stood up for what he believed was right, even if it got in the way of his personal well-being.

"I'd heard a rumor, Autumn," started Winston, meeting her outside her reptile enclosure, "Heard that Donald found out you were back to your old tricks."

Autumn's eyes widened just a tiny bit, almost imperceptible, a reaction only someone with Winston's training would catch.

"Imagine his surprise," continued Winston, "down in the bunker alone, knowing his old friend is involved in illegal matters again."

Autumn was silent, staring at the detective with an unreadable expression.

Donald's fatal allergy to snake venom was not a widely known fact, but one that Autumn was well aware of. Yet, Winston couldn't help but notice, but Autumn's snakes seemed to be unfazed and peaceful in their glass enclosures. Unusual for creatures known for their deadly bite.

It struck Winston odd as he mindfully stepped away from the enclosure, keeping Autumn under gaze, "I hope you aren't up to no good, Autumn, because secrets always find their way out."

Winston took another sip of his lukewarm coffee as he glanced upon the crime scene photos spread out on his desk. Donald's murder was an unusual one, a death by snake venom. He had always thought that underground bunkers were safe; this case was proving him wrong.

Word on the street was that Darnell was quite the character. A missionary, stationed in a region notorious for snakes, missionaries of that region were trained to extract snake venom due to the frequent encounters with these creatures. Winston lit a cigarette as he thought about Darnell's training. It seemed unusual for a man of god, but Winston quickly reminded himself that his job was not to question, rather to understand. Darnell, a black man with a calm demeanor, had a reputation for being gentle with the snakes, and his soft-spoken voice was often praised by the locals.

He stepped out of his office, coffee in hand, and made his way to the local church. He had arranged to meet Darnell there, hoping to gather some insights to this peculiar case.

Darnell was adjusting the chairs in the church when Winston walked in. As he approached Darnell helping his surroundings, Winston couldn't help but notice the lack of both vocal inflection and changing facial expressions in Darnell's greetings. Adding to that, Darnell never gave away a hint of his personal life during their meeting, always twisting the conversation towards his missionary tales.

Despite this, Winston listened attentively. Darnell's stories were filled with accounts of handling snakes, a talent he came to master during his time in the region. But as the detective prodded for more personal information, Darnell grew restless and god forbid, began to show signs of emotion, expertly redirecting the conversation to a less personal level.

Home from his meeting with Darnell, Winston could not ignore the oddities. Darnell was engaging but avoided personal questions. He was in a place full of snakes and had experience handling them. But could handling snakes lead to killing someone?

A conversation with a certain Father McNulty led to a shocking revelation. Darnell was allegedly smuggling drugs during his mission trips. It was a serious accusation, but if true, it could certainly pile on disastrous professional and personal consequences.

Snakebites remedies were common knowledge among missionaries, it became clear. A darker thought hit Winston, Darnell had both access and expertise in handling snake venom--a fact that couldn't be overlooked.

The final piece to the puzzle came from James, a local grocery-hand who had heard Donald confront Darnell about the drugs. It hadn't gone too well. Consequently, this planted a seed of doubt in Winston's mind.

Darnell had managed to combine what seemed like an altruistic role of a missionary with illicit activities. But the question remained--did he escalate these actions to murder? Winston stubbed out his cigarette and let out a tired puff of smoke. It would be a long night sorting through his clues.

context:
In the piercing silence of a New York night, Dwayne's life was brutally ended by a sickle's blade in his own car, launching Detective Winston into a dangerous game of truth and lies with suspects, Anthony and Darnell.

Winston was sitting in his dark office, squinting at the collection of photographs from the crime scene. Dwayne’s last ride – the car was a crime scene on its own. A car that belonged to Darnell, a dark-skinned man with a strong jawline.

The empty passenger seat next to where Dwayne’s life was taken was a jarring image, the shadow of the uneven coat hanger sticking out like some grotesque sculpture. Only two people on the scene – the deceased and the driver. Darnell.

A few nights ago, Winston had seen the two men together at an art exhibition, both appeared engaged in animated conversation before they left together, Dwayne accompanying Darnell to the car.

Ironically, that very evening at the exhibition, when the discussion began to focus on the art trade, Darnell excused himself to use the restroom - a habit he had too often displayed. He was strangely elusive when it came to conversations about the art dealing business. But that wasn’t all. Later that night, someone asked Darnell about a recent art heist. Startled by this, he quickly switched the conversation to discuss the latest sports news. Discussing the current performance of the local baseball team to be exact.

People attributed Darnell’s swift exits during trade talks as an eccentricity of an obsessed art lover, but they started becoming suspicious when Darnell's speedy departure followed the query about the art heist.

There's one thing about Artworld - reputation is everything. A tiny ink stain of scandal can become a tremendous blot on an art dealer’s reputation. Public humiliation, such as being caught up in a forgery scandal, could be the death sentence in this high-class world.

Darnell knew this, he had always been acutely aware that his hard-earned reputation lay on the basic premise of authenticity. He was proud of his reputation, often boasting about his record of dealing only in authentic pieces. But Dwayne had something else in mind. Word had it that he was preparing to expose one of Darnell’s famed pieces as a hoax at the next exhibit.

Winston decided it was high time he paid a visit to Darnell. The esteemed art dealer had some hard questions to answer.

Winston carefully brushed away the shards of glass that crunched under his brown leather brogues. This was not just any car. This was Dwayne's. The same car that Dwayne refused to cede possession of the keys to anyone, save for one...friend. Anthony.

He recalled his prior visit to Anthony's art studio. "The medium is just as important as the message," Anthony once told him. Winston, even then, captivated by the sculptural sequences of religious allegory, all lovingly carved by the man himself with a pottage of tools, including their shared favorite -- a sickle.

Anthony had recently poured his beliefs and faith into his work, passionately emphasizing his religious themes. His disquieting fervor was evident in every sculpture, each bearing an ominous sickle, a tool he had been using for the last five years.

Winston shuffled through his notes and found the transcript of a sermon given by Anthony, where he vehemently said the non-believers were threats. A veiled offensive, inspired by Dwayne, who never refrained from criticizing Anthony's religious art nor his belief systems, a matter that Anthony took immense offense to.

Anthony, no stranger to Dwayne's criticism, had requested a meeting with Dwayne. "Dwayne," he had written, "it's urgent. We meet by your car. You know the place." Anthony had the keys to the car belonging to the man he disagreed with most, the man whose disbelief became a source of disdain for him.

Winston remembered the sobering reality --- he now stood at the very location of their meet. Dwayne's car. A discovery that was both alarming and fascinating, considering Anthony was, to his knowledge, the only other person who had access to it.

Back at his office, Winston eyed the order forms, spread wide on his disheveled desk. Sickle after sickle being ordered in retrospect, all intended for Anthony's art projects.

"Why sickles? Isn't it a bit risqué in these times, Anthony?" Winston once asked him. Anthony merely laughed it off, avoiding the question. Today, as he pieced together the facts of Dwayne's demise, the laugh was rather disquieting.

Winston blew out a tired breath, tapping his pen against a stack of papers. This case was becoming a complex labyrinth, and Anthony, once just an artist fueled by his faith, was slowly emerging as a puzzle piece of bewildering proportions.

context:
In the piercing silence of a New York night, Dwayne's life was brutally ended by a sickle's blade in his own car, launching Detective Winston into a dangerous game of truth and lies with suspects, Darnell and Max.

As Winston continued his investigation, his next stop was to meet with Max. Max ran a popular art dealership in town, claiming to deal with artifacts too, and his reputation had charmed many art enthusiasts, including Dwayne.

Upon knocking, the door creaked open. Winston found himself in a large living space, filled with exquisite pieces of art, including a rather unique sickle, which was oddly intriguing.

"Max?" Winston called out, taking care not to disturb the artifacts around him.

Max returned from another room, a pleased grin on his face, his eyes kindling with pride," Ah, detective, welcome to my humble abode."

Max was a known art dealer who wasn't just after profit but cherished the art of curating a meaningful collection. From Winston's observation, Max appeared to be highly concerned about his reputation in this field.

When Winston asked, "Did Dwayne visit you last night?”, from the corner of his eye he noticed a flicker of unease cross Max’s face. Max hesitated before answering, "Yes, Detective. He wanted to take a look at my collection... he had a soft spot for historical farming artifacts."

As they chatted, Max admitted to giving Dwayne a ride afterward as Dwayne was his guest, and thought it only right to drive him back. Dwayne was seated in the passenger's seat of Max's car, he had said. It was in this same car where Dwayne's lifeless body was found later.

"So it was just the two of you going to the car?", Winston clarified, to which Max nodded, confirming that he was last seen with Dwayne heading towards the car.

As the discussion continued, Winston learnt from Max about an upcoming exhibit, where Dwayne planned to expose an inauthentic artifact in Max's collection, something that threatened Max’s reputation.

On leaving, Winston couldn't help but echo the words of an old mentor. In a world where reputation is synonymous with one's identity, public humiliation would surely be a blow to anyone's individuality.

With that he exited, leaving a rather perturbed Max behind him, contemplating the implications.

Winston found himself standing in the midst of Darnell's gallery. The room was a silent symphony of colors and emotions, none of which were gold. But gold was the color he was concerning himself with today. Darnell's housekeeper had testified that she found gold paint on his clothes after his various trips, an unusual finding considering none of his displayed art contained any hint of the metallic hue.

He stepped out to speak with the gallery owner, his heavy boots echoing slightly in the hushed rooms. "He uses gold paint?" Winston asked, waving a test report he had from Darnell's housekeeper.

"No, not ever in his career. Darnell's palette is more primary," the gallery owner stated, looking rather puzzled.

After a short nod, Winston tucked away the paper, and left the gallery. His next stop in the long journey would be to confront Darnell himself. Darnell had earlier on requested a meeting with Dwayne. He decided to use this unusual request as leverage, he agreed now to meet Winston by Dwayne's car, a location he knew well since he had keys to it. He pulled out his phone to arrange this unusual meeting.

Darnell looked a bit out of place amongst the urban landscape, amongst the shining cars. His dark skin stood out against the dull backdrop, and his wild black hair was a stark contrast to the surrounding environment. Colors smudged his skin artistically, and a keychain, bulky and jingling with keys, sat by his side.

"I had to pick up some of Dwayne's things", Darnell said, hand unconsciously stroking the keychain. "His woman couldn’t do it, she's a wreck."

"You had keys to his car?" Winston prompted.

"Well, yes, we were friends after all," Darnell replied, confirming his synaptic tie to Dwayne's automobile.

Winston decided to take a different approach for the kind of question that lay heavy on his mind. "Dwayne didn't share your religious beliefs, did he?" He said, more of a statement than a question.

Darnell's face twisted, his features hardened. "No, he didn't, the fool was way off the path. He never got my art, my sermons. I've often stated in my preachings that the nonbelievers like him were threatening the sanctity of our path."

Darnell looked uncomfortable when he realized what he had just said, and he tried to compose himself. "He needed help, that’s why I wanted to meet him. Sure, I was deeply offended by his criticism, but that doesn't make my concern any less valid."

"To convince him about your beliefs?" Winston posed, a touch of humanity in his tone.

"No, to make him understand my art!" Darnell's voice was emphatic. But he didn’t admit to painting with gold.

"There were disagreements then?" Winston asked, almost rhetorically.

A deep sigh rasped out from Darnell's mouth. "Yes, often. Unfortunately, I was unable to win him over."

He looked down at his hands, the same hands that relentlessly splashed beautiful, and often disturbing, illusions onto canvas. And then a grim realization reflected on his face, a bitter parting comment reminding him of the deep offense Dwayne’s criticism might have caused. The open space around Dwayne's car echoed with the ringing silence-the paradoxical sound of an artist remorseful.

"Ah, it doesn’t matter now." Darnell got up to leave, a sad brush of reality tinted his voice.

The man was an artist, devoted to his spiritual path to the point of obsession. But enough to commit a murder? Winston wondered, the many pieces of this puzzle yet to find their right place.

context:
In the ominous arena of a wrestling ring, Sophie's life was unexpectedly cut short by the deadly crack of a pistol; now it's up to grizzled Detective Winston to interrogate suspects Willard and Darnell, unmasking the murderer among them.

Winston sipped his coffee as he walked into the busy dealership, hidden behind large glass paneling. Beside the main floor was a separate storage area, cleverly concealed and invisible from the sales floor - tucked away in a quiet corner where no customer could see. Salesmen were bustling about, attempting to close deals and lure in unsuspecting customers. His gaze settled on a particular man, who was rather keenly explaining the mileage of a specific model to a customer: Darnell, a Black man with a deep voice.

"Mr. Darnell," Winston greeted in his stern tone, interrupting the technical talk about mileage.

"Sorry, sir. I'm deep in a conversation," he said, not looking up from the customer.

"I believe this is more important," Winston replied, flashing his badge.

Darnell made an excuse to the customer and led Winston toward the hidden storage room, away from the prying eyes of the staff and customers. Entering the secretive area that no other employee had set foot in, Darnell seemed visibly unnerved, surrounded by nothing but stacks of tires and car parts.

"Is there something wrong, detective?" He asked, subtly glancing at the locked door behind him.

"Darnell, I want to talk to you about Sophie. I understand you were both in the wrestling match. Quite the tough opponent you had there." Winston began.

Darnell cleared his throat, "Well, we were more than just opponents in the ring. We've had our issues politically too."

"I'm aware," Winston said curtly, noticing Darnell turning defensive.

"Sophie possessed evidence against you, she found out about money laundering carried out through this dealership, perhaps?" Winston probed.

Darnell shifted uncomfortably; his complexion changed and he cast his eyes down nervously. "I...I don't know what you're talking about, Detective."

Winston sternly replied, "Sophie planned to reveal these illegal acts. You knew it, didn’t you? She was about to expose your whole operation.”

"Anyone would want to protect their livelihood, Detective,” retorted Darnell, avoiding Winston's piercing gaze.

"I see," Winston said calmly assessing the situation, "It seems no one else knows what you do in this storage room Darnell."

“Well, it's my dealership, my storage. Do I need an audience now?" Darnell retorted, frustration creeping into his voice.

Deciding to change gears a bit, Winston asked, "Say, Darnell, you sponsor anyone in Sophie's campaign?"

"Actually I do, I have been secretly financing a competing candidate in Sophie's campaign." Revealed Darnell with a mischievous grin, sensing no immediate danger.

"Ah, hedging your bets, are we?" Winston concluded.

"Interesting," Winston said, ending the conversation. He finished up his lukewarm coffee, thanked Mr. Darnell for his time, and walked out of the concealed storage room, leaving Darnell behind in the stuffy room of tires and car parts.

As he meandered through the dealership, Winston thought about what Darnell had said and not said. He stepped out into the parking lot, squinting against the harsh afternoon sun. He had a mystery to solve, and every lead mattered.

Winston took another sip from his coffee cup as he shuffled through the files, his tired eyes narrowing on the name Willard, the initial suspect for the recent wrestling ring homicide. Sophie's death had hit the community like a brick wall, and the press swarmed around it like flies.

Sophie, a champion wrestler, was shot in the ring while performing one of her signature moves. The chaos of that night was still reported in the tabloids, time seemed to have stopped, and the investigation was now up to him.

Sophie had falsely accused Willard of malpractice, however, she won the court case. It was an incident that was the talk of the town. The accusations, though false, were ratified by court, leaving Willard's career on thin ice. Winston remembered Willard's hands shaking at the courthouse, his eyes burning with something Winston could not quite pinpoint.

Spotting Willard's front-row wrestling event ticket in the collected evidence file, Winston knew he had been there right at the heart of the event. It was well known that mandatory check-ins were required for attendees and part of Willard’s check-in document showed his presence at the entrance of the arena, confirming his presence at that fateful match.

The interviews had a common thread - Willard frequented the wrestling matches. Winston had found the receipts and tickets for each event annotated in Willard's handwriting; it was an unquestionable fact.

Dr. Willard's profile drew Winston's attention. His career required him using protective tools like support belts and gloves, but also a familiarity with the human anatomy that would be advantageous in a wrestling match. It was especially Willard’s second career—his military background—that caught Winston’s eye. Winston had heard about Willard's long career in the army. The firearm training he got there pulled him back to the murder.

Poring over reports again, Winston recalled that Willard carried a firearm for protection. The firearm was engraved into the case's backbone, another undeniable fact that Winston had to grapple with.

He took a deep breath and decided to pay Willard a visit.

Meeting Willard at his office, Winston perched himself on the edge of the chiropractic table, looking at the protective gloves and belts hanging on the wall, it was evident that his practice required these safety tools. Winston could see Willard's tension, the hint of uncontrollable worry seeping from his face. He handed over his business card to Willard.

"So, Willard, you were at the wrestling match the night Sophie was shot?" Winston asked.

Willard nodded, "Yes, I was there... I... I usually go to watch the matches. I had a front-row ticket."

Winston opened his notepad, marking it down. "The court case, it was... tough on you, wasn't it?" He asked.

Willard swallowed, nodding again without a word.

Winston stood up to leave, passing a quick glance over the firearms manual lying on the shelf, and pocketed his notepad. He didn't know if he had all the answers, but he was determined to find the truth.

In the quiet solitude of a local library, Philip is found shockingly murdered with a barbed wire, leaving Detective Winston with the arduous task of sifting truth from alibis of the two main suspects, Hugo and Ivory.

Stepping into the library, a sea of hushed whispers and tiptoeing patrons, detective Winston began his appointment with Hugo. Navigating his way through the maze of bookshelves and study cubicles, he found the man seated in a corner, engrossed in a tangle of wires and knobs. Hugo was a sound engineer. The smorgasbord of tools and wires – even a wild-looking barbed one often used in some peculiar sound gigs-, extending around him served as a testament to his profession and the variety of venues he worked in.

"Mr. Hugo?" Winston interrupted, his voice barely a notch above a whisper. Hugo nodded, eyelids still glued to his work. "I'm detective Winston. I hope I'm not interrupting," he casually commented, glancing at the array of wiring tangled in the engineer's hands.

He took notice of the barbed wire amongst the mix. A trace of unease settled in the back of his mind as he recalled the crime scene images: Philip, lifeless in the library-turned-crime scene, surrounded by scattered books and barbed wire.

After a moment, Hugo paused his work and leaned back, engaging the detective. Hugo mentioned a sound engineering job he was working on at the library at the time of Philip's murder. His work, he explained, often brought him to quiet, empty venues like this after dark, be it a library, an amphitheater, or something else entirely, each requiring specific types of wires and tools, barbed wire included.

"Bit of an unusual pick, isn't it?" Winston tried to sound nonchalant.

Hugo chuckled, revealing a collection of rare and unusual wires he'd acquired as part of his professional routines. He casually referred to his atypical collection as an occupational hazard, barbed wire included.

The conversation somehow segued to Hugo's family, particularly his brother. "He's not the responsible, betting kind," Hugo sighed, mentioning a lost gamble that cost his brother significantly. "Between you and me," he leaned in to confide, "Philip could be pretty aggressive when it came to his debts. In fact, he was known to resort to physical violence to get his way, a tendency that worried me always."

Detective Winston couldn't help but ask, "Did you confront him about it?"

"No, but..." Hugo hesitated before confessing a private phone call he overheard between Philip and his brother. Philip, as per Hugo, had not minced words in expressing his threats.

With his booked time slot over, Hugo readied to leave. Winston noticed the lights around them were already shutting down. The library often stayed vacant during Hugo's setup and takedown sessions, he mentioned nonchalantly.

As Winston left the dusky library, he contemplated the quiet bulk of sound equipment Hugo had in tow, wires of all sorts jingling together. It left a disquiet in his gut that he couldn't quite explain. But as a detective, he was trained to never jump to conclusions. After all, in a murder investigation, everything and everyone was a piece in the puzzle until proven otherwise.

As Winston walked into Ivory's salon, he was overrun by the smell of hair products and freshly brewed coffee. The salon itself was bustling, filled with happy chatter and the occasional hum of hair dryers. He was taken in by the sight of Ivory, her dark skin a warm contrast to the bright lights of the salon, working diligently on a customer's hair, using an abundance of sharp tools, from scissors to razors.

"Ivory?" called Winston.

She looked up, her eyes catching the sheen of the barbed hairpins on her tray. They looked dangerously sharp - almost eerily similar to barbed wire.

"Yes, that's me! Can I help you?" Ivory responded.

"Just have a few questions," Winston muttered.

Ivory's salon, open until 10 pm every evening, was bustling. As he waited for Ivory to finish with her current client, he couldn't help but notice a large unidentifiable bag resting in the corner.

Ivory then joined Winston, washing her hands before sitting across from him. "Detective, isn't it?" she said, having picked up on his official demeanor.

"I often see you at the library," Winston started, hoping his observation could break the ice.

Ivory's eyes twinkled as she answered, "Yes, that's true. I find it soothing to visit the library after I close the salon at 10 pm. It's open till then, making it a perfect addition to my schedule."

They went on, revealing Ivory's deep connection with the library—it came to the point where she became one of its registered trustees and was trusted with its key.

Later, the conversation shifted to her closing activities at the salon. It didn't take long for Winston to realize the purpose of the large unidentifiable bag. After closing, Ivory would routinely transport this bag to her car trunk, which she conveniently parked just outside.

"I heard from a neighbor that they've seen you cleaning your car in the parking lot after midnight," Winston remarked.

Ivory simply nodded, unfazed. "Yes, I tidy up my car after a long day at the salon. I usually carry my cleaning supplies in there—it's easier to keep things clean on the go."

The conversation then took a darker turn. Winston disclosed the tragic news of Philip's demise—he had been found murdered in the library. His time of death coincidentally coincided with Ivory's usual visits. The revelation hung heavy in the air, but Winston, true to his role, kept his thoughts in check. His job was to collect information. Deductions were left to the reader.

After expressing his gratitude to Ivory, Winston has left her to continue her work. Retreating to his car, he began considering his next line of inquiry, Philip's murder fresh on his mind.

To determine the most likely murderer, we must evaluate each suspect based on the three key criteria: means, motive, and opportunity.

**Hugo:**
- **Means:** Hugo had access to barbed wire, which was the murder weapon. As a sound engineer, he regularly used various wires, including barbed wire, for his work.

context:
In the quiet solitude of a local library, Philip is found shockingly murdered with a barbed wire, leaving Detective Winston with the arduous task of sifting truth from alibis of the two main suspects, Darnell and Maria.

Winston's mind was buzzing during the ride to the local hair salon, a tragic incident sinking his spirits. Philip, a library frequenter, was dead, with dire circumstances suggesting a gruesome murder. The weapon, a coil of barbed wire, unusual for sure. As he walked into the salon, he saw a middle-aged woman, Maria with a multitude of barbed hairpins reflecting ominously under the lights. She was working away with a pair of scissors, her nimble fingers managing both the razor and the various hairpins with the dexterity of an artist.

"Maria?" Winston asked.

Caught off guard, Maria looked up, her eyes wide in surprise. "Yes, detective, can I help you with something?" she answered, never pausing her delicate dance of grooming. She clicked her scissors, moved on to her razor, then her infamous collection of barbed hairpins, all with the practiced ease of someone in her profession for a long time.

"I hear you've been doing this for over fifteen years?" he asked, partially making small talk, partially feeling out the woman in front of him.

"Sixteen years, next Tuesday." She replied, her gaze deliberately focused on her current client's head.

"Quite a long time..." Winston said, thoughtful. "You ever do hair for a fellow called Philip?"

Maria paused for a moment, her eyes downcast. "Yes, I did his hair once. He's the one found in the library, right?"

"Yes," Winston nodded, "I heard about your usual evening strolls to the library. The one open late till 10 pm?"

"Yeah, it's quiet, peaceful. They don't mind if I bring my coffee inside. I even have a key, just in case I lose track of time and it's closing," Maria disclosed.

"I see. How about Robert? Phillip's fiance. He been here, recently?" Winston changed the subject.

Maria swallowed and cleared her throat, stepping away from her customer to face Winston. "Yes, he came... to talk."

"To talk about the wedding, or about that time in high school where you confessed your love to him before he proposed to Philip?" Winston probed.

Maria averted her eyes, "About the wedding... but, yes, we also brought up the past. I've been in love with Robert since high school, and I've been secretly carrying that love for years, you know."

Winston observed Maria. Things certainly aren't always as they seem, he thought, as she returned to her client, her barbed hairpins dancing in the slightly unsettling light. The fact that the time of Philip's death aligned eerily with Maria's usual library visit was an added layer of unease. "Well, Robert's supposed to marry Philip soon, isn't he?"

"Yes, but things aren't always as they seem, detective." Maria's voice held an edge as she responded, her gaze being both hurt yet defiant, hinting at a deeper tale yet to unravel.

Blowing off steam, jumping from coffee shop to coffee shop, Winston was back on track, unanswered questions regarding Philip's mysterious murder bouncing in his mind. Known for his capacity for violence to get what he wanted, Philip had a reputation; ironically, barbed wire, his common form of conflict resolution, had been the weapon.

The detectives at the precinct were all a twitter about the eccentric Darnell, a black man with a quiet demeanor. Out of all potential suspects they'd drawn in, one thing about Darnell was blinking on Winston's radar. Not once had any colleague, friend or customer ever been invited to his personal studio where Darnell spent most of his time. The man was protective of his private space, it seemed.

"I'm detouring to Darnell's office," Winston informed his partner as he made a left turn.

The professional layout of Darnell's studio stood testament to his skills. Winston noticed the different categories of wires neatly stowed away, labeled by type. Spools of common wires were neatly packed, then his gaze floated towards an unusual collection of unique wires, barbed wire included, labeled 'personal collection'. He stroked one with his gloved fingers, lost in thought.

"Darnell," Winston called for his attention, "This is some impressive collection. Not everyone works with barbed wire in a sound system, huh?" Darnell's smile was gentle, "I just like to keep my wire knowledge versatile," he shrugged.

"I heard you missed out on this year's industry conference," Winston inquired casually.

"Yeah. Conferences are not my cup of tea," Darnell chuckled, "Too much show and too little know. I prefer focusing on the actual job, here in my studio."

Casual chat moved reflective as Winston asked about Philip, "What about Philip? Ever get into a formal tussle with him?" Darnell's rifle through a box of cables paused, "No direct confrontation, sir, but I was an unfortunate audience to threats he made to my brother over a phone call. Nastiest conversation ever."

Winston nodded, taking in the distraught Darnell before himself. Darnell's brother owed a significant amount to Philip, everyone and their nephew knew that. It had been no blind gamble, but rather a bet gone awry. It had complicated Darnell's personal dynamics, certainly. Especially so since no one saw Darnell at the annual company holiday party. Usually a regular, Darnell's absence sent alerts.

Duty kept Darnell traveling between different venues for sound gigs, with a vast array of tools tagging all along, wires included, also, wires very similar to the ones found at Philip's crime scene. Winston mulled over this kaleidoscope of details, knowing well the devil lay in their details, as he drove back to the precinct.

context:
In the chilling aftermath of Iris' untimely death by a stun gun in a lonely parked car, seasoned detective Winston finds himself waist-deep in a web of intrigue involving two prime suspects, Paige and Ebony.

Winston pinched the bridge of his nose, tired from a long night of pouring over evidence. In his hands, he held a stack of emails, one of which indicated that Paige had set up a meeting with Iris on the day of her death. He had also discovered a certificate amongst Paige's belongings that showed she had completed a self-defense course complete with stun gun training. He also noticed that as Iris's direct subordinate, Paige was next in line to lead the company, particularly since Iris didn't have any family members who could inherit the role. Additionally, he held company accounts that show a gradual decline in profits, a likely result of Iris's stubbornness to cut staff numbers and her constant investment in unsuccessful projects.

An email, a key to Iris's car found among Paige's belongings confirming her access, a timestamp, and a set of scorched fingerprints were all he had. Adding to this, CCTV footage from the company consistently showed Iris's car parked at their workplace confirming her regular presence. Straightening up in his chair, he got up, stretched, and went to interview his next suspect on the list - Paige, who had recently been seen on CCTV footage purchasing a stun gun.

Making his way out of the police station, Winston found himself in a tall glass building, home to the company that Iris had managed. Upon entering, he confirmed with a coworker that the last person to see Iris alive was indeed Paige, taking Iris into a meeting.

"Detective Winston? Welcome," said Paige.

Winston glanced at the trash next to her desk, spotting a receipt from the stun gun shop that coincided with the CCTV footage and asked, "Have you been keeping up with your stun gun training?"

Paige looked taken aback, but answered, "Yes, I find it essential. Safety matters."

The detective nodded, an unease creeping up on him as he thought about the circumstances surrounding Iris's death, wondering whether the profits would rise once again now that Paige was stepping up.

Winston took a sip of his cold coffee as he lay his eyes on the glossy wedding album of Iris. Ebony, a woman with dark brown skin and curly black hair, must have done a flawless job for a wedding in this grandeur's scale.

He turned off the city streets, pulling into a small car park next to a utility store. Ebony was there, in the shop that sold stun guns among other things, surrounded by the cluttered mess of wires and bolts. Tagged along in her workspace was her office, filled with numerous taxidermy pufferfish that were unusually large and placed strategically for utmost visibility. As the owner, Ebony had to keep track of everything. Winston took a mental note of her electrical engineering degree framed on the wall.

"Ebony," Winston intoned as she finally looked up from her workbench.

"Detective," She greeted him coolly, "Here to pick a stun gun?"

"Actually, I'm looking into a case," Winston said, sliding the crime scene photos across the counter.

Ebony's eyes scanned them but she said nothing. Her hand didn't shake even when he laid out the receipt his team had found in her apartment. A receipt for a stun gun purchased a week ago.

"So, tell me about this," Winston motioned towards the pufferfish on her desk. Ebony’s eyes lit up as she started passionately rambling about the intricacies of it.

Winston picked up her laptop, left casually open on police databases. The business' financials weren't good - she was operating at a loss and had to borrow heavily from nontraditional lenders. This major wedding event must have been a boost for her, financially speaking.

Winston got up, preparing to leave. "Your work here, it's all very remarkable, Ebony."

"Thank you for your words, detective," she said, her gaze shifting once again to the photographs laid out on the bench.

Winston had no choice but to leave her to her pufferfish and stun guns. "Take care, Ebony," he said before walking out the door.

context:
In the chilling aftermath of Iris' untimely death by a stun gun in a lonely parked car, seasoned detective Winston finds himself waist-deep in a web of intrigue involving two prime suspects, Ebony and Alicia.

Pulling off his reading glasses, Detective Winston stared in thought at the computer screen. The emails between Iris and Ebony showed a scheduled meeting for the day of the murder. He looked over to Iris's company accounts and noticed a fall in profits that had been happening over some time.

"Is there anyone from Iris's family that could take over the company?" he asked his  young assistant who was pouring over police reports in the corner.

"No, she didn't have any family," the assistant called back.

As Winston dig deeper into the case, he found that Ebony, as Iris's direct subordinate, would be the next in line for company leadership. Questioning her could give him some more perspective.

He found her sitting in her office, fiddling with a set of keys. He couldn't help but notice she was surrounded by a collection of pens from various meets, a quirk that was both peculiar and endearing. However, his keen eye was caught by a hair tie that was nestled amongst the pens. Ebony's dark brown skin and tightly coiled black hair framed her somber expression as she worked.

"You pick that up recently?" He chimed, nodding towards the hair tie. Caught off guard, she nodded, "Yes, it was on the floor in the office." Winston just nodded, filing that information away for later.

Diving into their conversation, Ebony admitted that Iris was a dedicated boss, refusing to cut staff numbers and that she kept investing in unsuccessful projects, much to the chagrin of others. Ebony admitted to knowing about the company's deteriorating health, given Iris's stubborn management methods, yet, she seemed thoroughly sad about her boss's demise.

Just then, one of Ebony's employees entered, looking flustered. "I found something weird," she said, showing Winston something that looked like a keyhole behind a movable panel in Ebony’s desk... a stark contrast to the otherwise meticulous space around them. His curiosity piqued, Winston thanked them and left with a promise for further communication.

Walking around the company's parking lot, he noticed Iris's car often in the frame of the CCTV footage. A coworker who was pulling out of the lot told Winston about seeing Iris the night she died.

"Saw her going into that meeting with Ebony; she looked real tense, " the coworker indicated a glass cabin that evidently served as the meeting room.

Winston decided to question Ebony further. "Do you have a key to Iris's car by any chance?" A flicker of surprise flashed across Ebony's face as she answered, "Yes, I do. Is something wrong, Detective?"

"Not at all, just following up on some leads. Thank you for your time, Ma'am," he assured her before making his way back to his car.

Winston flicked through the paperwork once more, using the dull humming coming from the precinct to focus his thoughts. In front of him, there was a landscape photo featuring Alicia in action, surrounded by a sea of flower crowns and women in long dresses. She was a wedding planner, overseeing all the details, including the transportation.

He looked deeper into the photo and noticed an electronic store across the street, where a store associate had reported Alicia making a purchase. Winston remembered speaking to that associate, who confirmed Alicia bought a stun gun there. This was a store that also sold stun guns, which had recently been purchased by Alicia. It confirmed what he was told, she did work in such a shop part-time.

Winston glanced out his window, thinking pensive thoughts. The wedding required Iris’s car. It was Alicia’s job to ensure the car was used appropriately during the grand event. It certainly was a grand event, and it was a big payday for Alicia’s business.

“Detective Winston, we have new documents for you.” An officer placed a file on his desk with a 'thump'. Financial statements. Alicia’s business wasn’t doing well. In fact, it was operating at a loss.

Heaving a sigh, Winston packed the files into his case. He made his way to Alicia’s apartment. As he walked through the entrance, his gaze fell upon a ledge where the mail was neatly stacked. He could see a receipt peeping out. With a pair of thin gloves, he picked it up. A receipt from the shop. The same shop where Alicia was seen buying a stun gun.

He knew Alicia had studied electrical engineering during her college years. She would definitely know how to use it. His mobile device buzzed then, alerting him to a new email. It contained background info on Alicia's financials. A different kind of record... Alicia had been borrowing heavily, and mostly not from banks. Nontraditional lenders... not an ideal situation to be in.

Stepping outside, Winston lit a cigarette, his hand steady, but mind racing. But then, his phone buzzed again with a new update from precinct. There were multiple eyewitnesses who reported seeing Alicia and Iris together just before the incident. The last time they'd been seen together, was leaving the wedding rehearsal. The same evening when the incident happened.

“Just the facts, Winston. Just the facts,” he said to himself, squashing out the cigarette and returning inside. There was more to uncover, and Alicia just happened to be at the center of it. Time would reveal the truth.
